episodes.title: Low-Cost Resources for Small Business
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.486
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.486 --> 00:00:08.231
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.231 --> 00:00:12.488
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.488 --> 00:00:15.003
>> Hi, thanks for joining us on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.003 --> 00:00:17.976
I'm Joshua Marpet, and
this is Scott Lyons, we're from Red Lion.

6
00:00:17.976 --> 00:00:22.380
We're gonna do a quick-fire talk on
low-cost resources for small business.

7
00:00:22.380 --> 00:00:25.522
So, Scott, start us off, what kind
of resources are we talking about?

8
00:00:25.522 --> 00:00:27.150
>> Well, in small businesses,

9
00:00:27.150 --> 00:00:30.283
a lot of small businesses
really rely on communication.

10
00:00:30.283 --> 00:00:34.744
They rely on project management, a little
bit of document management because, hey,

11
00:00:34.744 --> 00:00:37.280
you need a place to be
able to put your stuff.

12
00:00:37.280 --> 00:00:40.520
>> Okay, so what kind of resources
would you use for communication?

13
00:00:40.520 --> 00:00:44.620
>> Well, personally my personal favorite,
not gonna lie,

14
00:00:44.620 --> 00:00:49.810
I break the holy truth of communication
don'ts, and that's using Facebook.

15
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:55.160
Realistically, you shouldn't do that, but
I am a huge, huge breaker of that rule,

16
00:00:55.160 --> 00:00:59.440
only because everybody that
I know is there, so why not?

17
00:00:59.440 --> 00:01:02.033
Versus having Slack, right?

18
00:01:02.033 --> 00:01:06.610
>> That's true because, with Slack,
you have to be on a specific team.

19
00:01:06.610 --> 00:01:11.291
With Gtalk, you have to know which
address they have their Gtalk set up on.

20
00:01:11.291 --> 00:01:14.980
With Facebook, everybody's right there,
they're all in the same sort of grouping.

21
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:18.130
And if they're a friend of yours, you can
immediately message them and talk to them.

22
00:01:18.130 --> 00:01:22.136
But it's monitored, it's subpoenable,
it's easily get at people.

23
00:01:22.136 --> 00:01:23.504
It's not a good idea.

24
00:01:23.504 --> 00:01:26.152
So we recommend anything but Facebook.

25
00:01:26.152 --> 00:01:30.352
Signal, Slack, Gmail any of those things,
please use them instead of

26
00:01:30.352 --> 00:01:36.018
Facebook Messenger, but if you have to, as
Scott apparently always does, it's there.

27
00:01:36.018 --> 00:01:38.070
>> Yeah, but
you also have to remember, though,

28
00:01:38.070 --> 00:01:40.440
it comes down to the level
of communication.

29
00:01:40.440 --> 00:01:42.490
If you're talking about
company trade secrets,

30
00:01:42.490 --> 00:01:43.960
you sort of want an encrypted chat.

31
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:45.919
Facebook is not what you wanna use.

32
00:01:47.620 --> 00:01:48.520
Ain't that the truth?

33
00:01:48.520 --> 00:01:49.350
>> Yes, absolutely.

34
00:01:49.350 --> 00:01:53.412
>> But in being able to talk to
people about communication also

35
00:01:53.412 --> 00:01:55.372
comes project management.

36
00:01:55.372 --> 00:01:58.865
So for you,
when we're going through projects,

37
00:01:58.865 --> 00:02:02.820
what do you like to use
to manage the projects?

38
00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:06.310
>> So in actuality,
there's several things that I've used.

39
00:02:06.310 --> 00:02:09.160
I've used Trello, I've used Producteev.

40
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:12.890
For BSides Delaware, the conference that
I run, we use Producteev and Trello.

41
00:02:12.890 --> 00:02:15.250
For my house,
my wife setup a Trello board, so

42
00:02:15.250 --> 00:02:17.025
I would have a honey do
list that was perfect.

43
00:02:17.025 --> 00:02:19.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> Everything from taking out the garbage

44
00:02:19.500 --> 00:02:22.560
to folding the laundry to fixing
the plumbing is on our Trello list for

45
00:02:22.560 --> 00:02:23.100
the house.

46
00:02:24.230 --> 00:02:27.770
Evernote is a great one because it allows
you to put snippets of web pages and

47
00:02:27.770 --> 00:02:28.890
everything else in there.

48
00:02:28.890 --> 00:02:29.740
It depends.

49
00:02:29.740 --> 00:02:33.330
Trello is a Kanban board, or
think of Post-it notes on a white board.

50
00:02:33.330 --> 00:02:38.745
Producteev is more project based like
Asana where you have tasks that tricked

51
00:02:38.745 --> 00:02:43.415
together or linked together to do the task
one, then task two, then task three.

52
00:02:43.415 --> 00:02:45.205
So it depends, but
all of these are free versions.

53
00:02:45.205 --> 00:02:47.165
So it's very,
very low cost and very simple.

54
00:02:47.165 --> 00:02:50.070
>> Right, and
a lot of the free versions follow the same

55
00:02:50.070 --> 00:02:53.040
theory of project management,
whether it's the hybrid model,

56
00:02:53.040 --> 00:02:57.080
the DevOps model, the Waterfall model,
they're all baked into these systems.

57
00:02:57.080 --> 00:03:00.770
And that's really what's most important is
that they're flexible for your business.

58
00:03:00.770 --> 00:03:02.850
>> Right, because,
if you're an Agile firm.

59
00:03:02.850 --> 00:03:06.810
If you do Agile development, you're gonna
want to use a Kanban board like Trello or

60
00:03:06.810 --> 00:03:08.290
you're gonna want to use,
if you're Waterfall,

61
00:03:08.290 --> 00:03:11.020
you're gonna want to use
a Waterfall-based system or

62
00:03:11.020 --> 00:03:14.520
something that's Waterfall sort of
baked into its genes, like Producteev.

63
00:03:14.520 --> 00:03:17.790
You can do Agile on Producteev, but
it's a little different to set up.

64
00:03:17.790 --> 00:03:19.300
But again, even to do these things,

65
00:03:19.300 --> 00:03:22.041
you've gotta figure out where
you're gonna save all your stuff.

66
00:03:22.041 --> 00:03:25.308
>> And that's actually a really good
point, because it brings us into the next

67
00:03:25.308 --> 00:03:28.490
part of our discussion here which
is document management, okay?

68
00:03:28.490 --> 00:03:31.500
Now me personally,
I love using Google Docs.

69
00:03:31.500 --> 00:03:32.770
Google Docs for everything.

70
00:03:32.770 --> 00:03:34.240
It makes things really simple.

71
00:03:34.240 --> 00:03:37.360
The cost benefit value is there,
especially for

72
00:03:37.360 --> 00:03:41.950
a small business that might not have
access to enterprise level resources.

73
00:03:41.950 --> 00:03:44.740
>> Yeah, except that Google Docs
is a nightmare to keep organized,

74
00:03:44.740 --> 00:03:48.180
because if you create it or I created it,
it's now in different folders.

75
00:03:48.180 --> 00:03:52.150
And if we have folders of the same name,
it's impossible to merge them together.

76
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:56.700
So one friend of ours, Kevin Johnson from
Secure Ideas, actually had a great idea.

77
00:03:56.700 --> 00:04:01.040
He created a single master folder in
Google Docs and everybody in the firm puts

78
00:04:01.040 --> 00:04:04.110
all of their things, all of their
documents, in that master folder.

79
00:04:04.110 --> 00:04:07.540
That's worked, and we actually have
done that with some of our subcompanies.

80
00:04:07.540 --> 00:04:11.560
And some of our subcompanies somebody
started stuff that didn't do that and

81
00:04:11.560 --> 00:04:12.790
I got a little annoyed with them.

82
00:04:12.790 --> 00:04:14.510
I'm not saying it was
anybody in particular,

83
00:04:14.510 --> 00:04:17.130
I'm just pointing it out, let's say.

84
00:04:17.130 --> 00:04:20.250
But there's plenty of document management
projects and systems out there.

85
00:04:20.250 --> 00:04:25.693
There's Google Docs, there's GitHub,
there's Dropbox, there's Citrix.

86
00:04:25.693 --> 00:04:27.115
I forget the shares.

87
00:04:27.115 --> 00:04:32.666
>> AWS, you can use the S3 buckets
in AWS to do storage as well.

88
00:04:32.666 --> 00:04:33.840
>> Absolutely, that's correct.

89
00:04:33.840 --> 00:04:36.300
But there's lots of them out there.

90
00:04:36.300 --> 00:04:39.080
AWS actually charges for the S3 buckets,
so that's technically not free but

91
00:04:39.080 --> 00:04:40.650
it's relatively inexpensive.

92
00:04:40.650 --> 00:04:44.470
>> And either way you look at it, you need
to have security built-in to what you do,

93
00:04:44.470 --> 00:04:47.692
so you're looking at Google
authenticator for your two factor,

94
00:04:47.692 --> 00:04:53.218
you're looking at let's encrypt,
and https, all the things.

95
00:04:53.218 --> 00:04:57.390
>> Well that's https everywhere which is
a project that was started I think by

96
00:04:57.390 --> 00:05:01.510
Google, maybe even Facebook, but you'll
notice as you wander around the web these

97
00:05:01.510 --> 00:05:08.140
days most every major website is now https
with the green padlock on some browsers.

98
00:05:08.140 --> 00:05:10.804
If it's not SSL or TLS encrypted,
to be honest with you,

99
00:05:10.804 --> 00:05:14.390
is the correct way to say it, if it's not
TLS encrypted, you shouldn't be using it.

100
00:05:14.390 --> 00:05:16.932
It means you're pushing information
across an unsecure connection,

101
00:05:16.932 --> 00:05:20.960
that's an insecure connection that
just will not secure your information.

102
00:05:20.960 --> 00:05:24.160
So you've got to make sure that you're
two-factor, multi-factor in some form or

103
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:27.750
fashion, you're getting another factor
of authentication into your document

104
00:05:27.750 --> 00:05:31.290
management, into your sales management,
into all of the things that you do as

105
00:05:31.290 --> 00:05:34.590
a business, because otherwise
you're risking everything you have.

106
00:05:34.590 --> 00:05:37.110
>> Okay, so let's say you
walk down all of these roads.

107
00:05:37.110 --> 00:05:40.168
You do all the basics, you've watched
the talks that we've put out.

108
00:05:40.168 --> 00:05:42.997
And you say, hey, I have this
great thing called customers, and

109
00:05:42.997 --> 00:05:44.840
now I have money coming in, okay?

110
00:05:44.840 --> 00:05:48.320
So the last two topics that I wanna talk
about real quick are, what do we do for

111
00:05:48.320 --> 00:05:49.560
our customers?

112
00:05:49.560 --> 00:05:52.710
And what are good options for
managing your money?

113
00:05:52.710 --> 00:05:55.590
>> Okay, so for customers, you want a CRM,

114
00:05:55.590 --> 00:05:58.090
that's a customer relationship
management system.

115
00:05:58.090 --> 00:06:01.230
There's Hub Spot, there's Salesforce,
there's a lot of different ones out there.

116
00:06:01.230 --> 00:06:05.262
There's xZro, X-Z-R-O,
there's several out there.

117
00:06:05.262 --> 00:06:06.890
>> Salesforce?

118
00:06:06.890 --> 00:06:08.380
Salesforce is super pricey.

119
00:06:08.380 --> 00:06:12.260
It's great, don't get me wrong, but the
price, especially for a small business,

120
00:06:12.260 --> 00:06:13.880
can be astronomical.

121
00:06:13.880 --> 00:06:15.890
>> Okay, that's a good point,
but it depends.

122
00:06:15.890 --> 00:06:16.960
Let me explain.

123
00:06:16.960 --> 00:06:19.910
Salesforce has the best
integrations out there in terms of

124
00:06:19.910 --> 00:06:21.820
customer relationship management systems.

125
00:06:21.820 --> 00:06:25.640
If your product or something you do with
a partner or some part of your business

126
00:06:25.640 --> 00:06:28.620
relies on those integrations,
you're gonna buy into Salesforce.

127
00:06:28.620 --> 00:06:31.390
Yeah, it's about 150
bucks a month per person.

128
00:06:31.390 --> 00:06:32.110
But you know what?

129
00:06:32.110 --> 00:06:33.190
If you need those integrations,

130
00:06:33.190 --> 00:06:36.015
an API integration with something,
you're gonna buy Salesforce.

131
00:06:36.015 --> 00:06:37.330
It's just that simple.

132
00:06:37.330 --> 00:06:39.830
Now if you had to buy stuff,
you gotta track your money.

133
00:06:39.830 --> 00:06:40.430
So how are you gonna do it?

134
00:06:40.430 --> 00:06:42.160
How are you gonna take money
if you're doing retail?

135
00:06:42.160 --> 00:06:45.260
And how are you gonna track money
if you're doing basic accounting,

136
00:06:45.260 --> 00:06:46.980
which I hope you're doing as a business.

137
00:06:46.980 --> 00:06:48.610
It's just a detail thing.

138
00:06:48.610 --> 00:06:52.700
So if you wanna take money,
you're gonna wanna use either Square or

139
00:06:52.700 --> 00:06:54.941
any of the phone-enabled readers.

140
00:06:54.941 --> 00:06:58.054
In other words, you plug it into your
phone through the headphone jack or

141
00:06:58.054 --> 00:07:01.527
through the bottom port, whether it's
Lightning or a Micro USB or a USB-C, and

142
00:07:01.527 --> 00:07:02.770
you can swipe a credit card.

143
00:07:02.770 --> 00:07:04.130
They even have EMV readers now.

144
00:07:04.130 --> 00:07:05.160
Square I know has them.

145
00:07:05.160 --> 00:07:08.380
I believe First Data has them as well,
where you can slide their chip readers.

146
00:07:08.380 --> 00:07:10.570
So where you can slide the card in and
read the chip.

147
00:07:10.570 --> 00:07:12.310
Okay, that's good for taking in money.

148
00:07:12.310 --> 00:07:15.050
But when you're out and
you have to go to business meetings.

149
00:07:15.050 --> 00:07:17.840
And you have lunches and
you have to get Ubers, and this, that, and

150
00:07:17.840 --> 00:07:20.470
the other, how do you keep
track of all those receipts?

151
00:07:20.470 --> 00:07:22.760
>> So there's two ways that you do that.

152
00:07:22.760 --> 00:07:25.960
One is you can use an app that's
designed for keeping track of receipts.

153
00:07:25.960 --> 00:07:28.440
Expensify is something I've
been pushing for years.

154
00:07:28.440 --> 00:07:30.020
I think it's a great app.

155
00:07:30.020 --> 00:07:32.130
Concur is another one, but
that's more enterprise based.

156
00:07:32.130 --> 00:07:34.640
Expensify you can do on your own,
and if you join a company,

157
00:07:34.640 --> 00:07:36.070
they can have a corporate
Expensify account.

158
00:07:36.070 --> 00:07:37.160
It's really, really simple.

159
00:07:37.160 --> 00:07:38.900
You literally take a picture
of the receipt and

160
00:07:38.900 --> 00:07:40.240
boom, it's in your Expensify account.

161
00:07:40.240 --> 00:07:42.600
And you say it's billable,
here's the client it's billable to, and

162
00:07:42.600 --> 00:07:45.640
it's reimbursable to me, Here's
the account I wanna get reimbursed from.

163
00:07:45.640 --> 00:07:46.860
It's simple, straightforward.

164
00:07:46.860 --> 00:07:52.380
>> So as a good recap, for communication,
use Slack or WhatsApp, not Facebook.

165
00:07:52.380 --> 00:07:57.110
For project management, you want Evernote
or Trello, right, or Producteev, right?

166
00:07:58.140 --> 00:08:02.020
For document management, it all depends
on what your business is doing,

167
00:08:02.020 --> 00:08:03.890
on how you wanna manage your documents,

168
00:08:03.890 --> 00:08:08.230
because that's really what it comes
down to, what fits for your business.

169
00:08:08.230 --> 00:08:11.770
For security, make sure that you're
always using encryption, right?

170
00:08:11.770 --> 00:08:15.470
For CRM, you wanna look at HubSpot
if you're a small business or

171
00:08:15.470 --> 00:08:17.690
something that's along
the lines of HubSpot.

172
00:08:17.690 --> 00:08:19.860
It's not as pricey as Salesforce,

173
00:08:19.860 --> 00:08:22.740
although you may find Salesforce
fits your needs for your business.

174
00:08:22.740 --> 00:08:25.790
Again, it all comes back to how
do you run your business and

175
00:08:25.790 --> 00:08:28.150
how do you tailor your business, right?

176
00:08:28.150 --> 00:08:32.500
For money, it depends on whether
you're taking cash in over the web,

177
00:08:32.500 --> 00:08:36.480
whether you're taking it in over a card,
right, and how you're managing

178
00:08:36.480 --> 00:08:41.020
what's going on with your money,
whether you're using QuickBooks for

179
00:08:41.020 --> 00:08:46.070
your accounting, or you're using Expensify
to track you receipts for your accountant.

180
00:08:46.070 --> 00:08:51.520
Either way, these are couple of small tips
about low cost resources for business.

181
00:08:51.520 --> 00:08:53.360
I'm Scott, this is Josh.

182
00:08:53.360 --> 00:08:55.789
Thanks for watching.

183
00:08:55.789 --> 00:09:01.814
[MUSIC]

184
00:09:01.814 --> 00:09:08.709
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.title: Entrepreneur's Rollercoaster
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.035 --> 00:00:06.273
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.273 --> 00:00:08.180
Hello, and welcome to BIZPRO.TV.

3
00:00:08.180 --> 00:00:13.060
Today, we are gonna be having a fire talk
about the entrepreneurial roller coaster.

4
00:00:13.060 --> 00:00:16.210
We are gonna be talking about the highs,
the lows, the goods, the bads.

5
00:00:16.210 --> 00:00:19.830
We are gonna be talking about everything
that goes into being an entrepreneur, but

6
00:00:19.830 --> 00:00:21.710
we're gonna do it in a very short segment.

7
00:00:21.710 --> 00:00:23.058
So my name is Scott.

8
00:00:23.058 --> 00:00:25.640
I am the CEO of Red Lion.

9
00:00:25.640 --> 00:00:29.900
I am an aficionado of the school
of hard business knocks.

10
00:00:29.900 --> 00:00:33.380
I've been around the block
when it comes to business.

11
00:00:33.380 --> 00:00:37.260
I do hold certifications in
the information security arena.

12
00:00:37.260 --> 00:00:40.430
And I'm not gonna say which but
my passions are people in business.

13
00:00:40.430 --> 00:00:45.010
Standing next to me right here
my other co-host is Josh Marpet.

14
00:00:45.010 --> 00:00:45.930
>> Thank you.
>> Great.

15
00:00:45.930 --> 00:00:47.760
>> And I'm gonna kick it to Josh.

16
00:00:47.760 --> 00:00:49.360
>> Hey, I'm Josh Marpet.

17
00:00:49.360 --> 00:00:52.873
I am former CEO of a start-up company.

18
00:00:52.873 --> 00:00:56.652
I graduated from the MACH37 Accelerator
in Herndon, Virginia.

19
00:00:56.652 --> 00:00:59.810
And I'm intimately familiar with
the entrepreneurial roller coaster.

20
00:00:59.810 --> 00:01:02.170
I lived it for a long time.

21
00:01:02.170 --> 00:01:04.952
It's not fun, and
that's where we came up with this talk.

22
00:01:04.952 --> 00:01:07.692
So, I'm the COO of Red Lion now.

23
00:01:07.692 --> 00:01:12.429
And notice I'm not the CEO, and I was
happy not to be, let's put it that way.

24
00:01:12.429 --> 00:01:14.751
So let's talk about
the entrepreneurial roller coaster.

25
00:01:14.751 --> 00:01:18.878
So effectively, the entrepreneurial
roller coaster is the idea that one day

26
00:01:18.878 --> 00:01:22.317
you're going to make a sale and
go, I'm at the top of the world.

27
00:01:22.317 --> 00:01:23.906
>> [SOUND]
>> Everything is amazing.

28
00:01:23.906 --> 00:01:25.649
We're gonna be great.

29
00:01:25.649 --> 00:01:31.667
And then the next day you didn’t make a
sale anymore, and we're all going to die.

30
00:01:31.667 --> 00:01:33.180
We're doomed, it’s going to fail.

31
00:01:33.180 --> 00:01:36.207
>> Quick stock up on Ramen,
stock up on Ramen.

32
00:01:36.207 --> 00:01:38.106
>> I’ve done that.

33
00:01:38.106 --> 00:01:40.830
>> I have too, that’s why I’m saying it.

34
00:01:40.830 --> 00:01:44.540
Because we live this every day.

35
00:01:44.540 --> 00:01:47.871
The rise and fall if you will of sales.

36
00:01:47.871 --> 00:01:50.872
>> So, let's talk about this for a second.

37
00:01:50.872 --> 00:01:51.640
What kind of situations
are gonna make you feel good?

38
00:01:51.640 --> 00:01:56.870
What kind of situations
are gonna make you feel bad?

39
00:01:56.870 --> 00:01:59.870
What kind of situations are gonna make
you feel like the world is spinning

40
00:01:59.870 --> 00:02:00.630
out of control?

41
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:06.863
>> Yeah, you know,
when you really sit back and

42
00:02:06.863 --> 00:02:11.350
you look at how the entrepreneur works and
lives in today's economy and market,

43
00:02:11.350 --> 00:02:16.620
it's kind of interesting to see if
businesses actually get off the ground.

44
00:02:17.730 --> 00:02:18.640
>> It's difficult.

45
00:02:18.640 --> 00:02:19.331
It's very difficult.

46
00:02:19.331 --> 00:02:23.725
You've got businesses that are not
able to get off the ground.

47
00:02:23.725 --> 00:02:27.535
But everybody inside the business
is obsessed with it saying,

48
00:02:27.535 --> 00:02:31.365
we're gonna be a billion dollar business,
we just have to make that first sale.

49
00:02:31.365 --> 00:02:35.672
You've got businesses that
are high-flying and then all of a sudden,

50
00:02:35.672 --> 00:02:39.187
the CEO is revealed to be a harasser and
a general scumbag,

51
00:02:39.187 --> 00:02:42.442
and then they're falling
as fast as you can imagine.

52
00:02:42.442 --> 00:02:44.430
>> Right, right, right.

53
00:02:44.430 --> 00:02:48.130
>> Success is no predictor of your
mental mood, trust me on this.

54
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:50.140
You can be doing amazingly well and

55
00:02:50.140 --> 00:02:52.260
still feel like you're
about to go over the cliff.

56
00:02:52.260 --> 00:02:56.060
>> So
you're telling me there's no Myers-Briggs

57
00:02:56.060 --> 00:02:59.780
way of being able to define who is and
who is not a success?

58
00:02:59.780 --> 00:03:02.980
>> Well, success, this is a good point.

59
00:03:02.980 --> 00:03:07.490
Success is financial,
success is long term business viability,

60
00:03:07.490 --> 00:03:11.380
success is mental health,
success is a lot of things.

61
00:03:11.380 --> 00:03:13.340
You can be incredibly
successful financially and

62
00:03:13.340 --> 00:03:16.990
have millions of dollars in the bank
as a cash reserve and still feel like

63
00:03:16.990 --> 00:03:21.560
you're a failure because you're not as
big as the competitor over thataways.

64
00:03:21.560 --> 00:03:22.580
And if that's the case,

65
00:03:22.580 --> 00:03:25.160
then you've got a problem,
because you're gonna be miserable.

66
00:03:25.160 --> 00:03:28.920
You're not gonna take time off cuz
you're gonna work 27 hours a day,

67
00:03:28.920 --> 00:03:32.660
furiously working to get
bigger than Competitor X and

68
00:03:32.660 --> 00:03:35.280
you're gonna be a miserable wreck and
your family life is dead.

69
00:03:35.280 --> 00:03:37.602
>> So are you telling me,
let me help you translate here,

70
00:03:37.602 --> 00:03:41.248
because this is the way that it's coming
across, what you're saying to me, right?

71
00:03:41.248 --> 00:03:42.300
>> Okay.

72
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:45.640
>> Is that we have to deal with
stress as an entrepreneur,

73
00:03:45.640 --> 00:03:48.970
we have to deal with a lot of stress,
all the time?

74
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:51.350
>> Not just stress, but
a lot of other things.

75
00:03:51.350 --> 00:03:55.540
When you're an entrepreneur, especially an
entrepreneurial CEO, you're stressed out.

76
00:03:55.540 --> 00:03:58.770
It's almost an occupational hazard,
it's a fact of life.

77
00:03:58.770 --> 00:04:01.650
You're stressed beyond normal people.

78
00:04:01.650 --> 00:04:04.790
I mean people have committed suicide,
people have died, people have had heart

79
00:04:04.790 --> 00:04:08.270
attacks, people have developed heart
problems because of the stress.

80
00:04:08.270 --> 00:04:11.260
You're lonely because you may have
people that work for you, but

81
00:04:11.260 --> 00:04:15.300
unless they've been a CEO, how are they
going to know what you're going through?

82
00:04:15.300 --> 00:04:17.350
It is an entirely different feeling.

83
00:04:17.350 --> 00:04:18.970
They're worried about
making their paycheck.

84
00:04:18.970 --> 00:04:22.463
You're worried about making their
paycheck, your paycheck, the healthcare

85
00:04:22.463 --> 00:04:26.380
that you've gotta buy, the sales that
you've gotta make, the, you get the idea.

86
00:04:26.380 --> 00:04:27.050
>> Right, right, right.

87
00:04:27.050 --> 00:04:31.090
So one of the things that we like to
preach about when we're going through and

88
00:04:31.090 --> 00:04:33.880
doing these business talks is
that when you hire somebody,

89
00:04:33.880 --> 00:04:35.740
it's not a key marker of success.

90
00:04:35.740 --> 00:04:40.330
What it really is is the fact that you
have another mortgage that you're taking

91
00:04:40.330 --> 00:04:41.970
on, right?

92
00:04:41.970 --> 00:04:45.860
>> You have a wonderful thing when you
have a business that grows enough for

93
00:04:45.860 --> 00:04:47.130
you to get some employees.

94
00:04:47.130 --> 00:04:50.360
That is fantastic,
it's a great marker of success.

95
00:04:50.360 --> 00:04:53.470
It also means that you've
now taken on people who are,

96
00:04:53.470 --> 00:04:55.440
think of them as your kingdom.

97
00:04:55.440 --> 00:04:59.120
You've taken on people who
are now responsible to you, but

98
00:04:59.120 --> 00:05:01.390
you're responsible to them to
make sure that there is business,

99
00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:04.850
there is opportunity, there is money,
there are paychecks going on.

100
00:05:04.850 --> 00:05:09.496
Let's say you fail three months in,
because that's a constant worry for a CEO,

101
00:05:09.496 --> 00:05:12.653
If you fail,
you've now broken your promise to them.

102
00:05:12.653 --> 00:05:16.150
You've now broken the promise that you
would be there and building the business.

103
00:05:16.150 --> 00:05:20.090
How is that gonna make you feel, and
worrying about that kind of feeling

104
00:05:20.090 --> 00:05:24.030
is absolutely terrifying to a CEO.

105
00:05:24.030 --> 00:05:27.900
>> Now, at the time that we're recording
this talk that you're watching right now,

106
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:30.950
we are actually streaming this
over Facebook Live, right?

107
00:05:30.950 --> 00:05:35.724
And we had somebody ping us on Facebook
Live and made a great, great point.

108
00:05:35.724 --> 00:05:40.680
Duncan says,
shouldn't one immediately define what

109
00:05:40.680 --> 00:05:45.458
success means for
both of them before they launch business.

110
00:05:45.458 --> 00:05:49.050
For example, is it money, is it freedom
and that's actually a really good point.

111
00:05:49.050 --> 00:05:49.707
>> That's a great question.

112
00:05:49.707 --> 00:05:50.800
It's a great point.

113
00:05:50.800 --> 00:05:52.676
>> That's a great question,
so let's answer that.

114
00:05:52.676 --> 00:05:57.672
So if you're going to launch a business,
you have an idea of what success is.

115
00:05:57.672 --> 00:06:01.000
Does it mean that you ironed it
out to an absolute certainty?

116
00:06:01.000 --> 00:06:03.080
No.
Does it mean that even once you've ironed

117
00:06:03.080 --> 00:06:06.150
it out and once you've created that
business, that that won't change?

118
00:06:06.150 --> 00:06:07.940
No, it can still change.

119
00:06:07.940 --> 00:06:11.330
You might start a business because that
problem that you're starting the business

120
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:15.850
around pisses you off so much that you're
gonna see that everybody has the solution,

121
00:06:15.850 --> 00:06:17.740
so nobody ever has that problem again.

122
00:06:17.740 --> 00:06:18.720
Now, of course, along the way,

123
00:06:18.720 --> 00:06:21.070
you wanna be able to support
yourself while doing it.

124
00:06:21.070 --> 00:06:23.660
Along the way, you wanna be able to
create some value for the world.

125
00:06:23.660 --> 00:06:25.740
That's kind of a common thing.

126
00:06:25.740 --> 00:06:27.690
But it doesn't mean that along
the way you don't realize,

127
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:30.940
wow I could make $50 million
selling this solution.

128
00:06:32.070 --> 00:06:34.370
I'm pretty comfortable with
that as a measure of success.

129
00:06:34.370 --> 00:06:35.690
That's not bad, you know.

130
00:06:35.690 --> 00:06:39.405
>> But some people just want to have
a business that subsists, okay?

131
00:06:39.405 --> 00:06:43.080
It just goes along, it generates money and
it really doesn't scale up, scale down.

132
00:06:43.080 --> 00:06:44.280
It just floats.

133
00:06:44.280 --> 00:06:46.970
>> Well that’s a lifestyle consultancy,
that’s the term for it.

134
00:06:46.970 --> 00:06:48.020
It’s a lifestyle consultancy.

135
00:06:48.020 --> 00:06:51.290
It allows me to live in a lifestyle
to which I’ve become accustomed to.

136
00:06:51.290 --> 00:06:55.510
And it allows me to live at my $100,000,
$300,000, $500,000 a year and

137
00:06:55.510 --> 00:06:58.030
it never really changes.

138
00:06:58.030 --> 00:07:01.640
I'm not interested in taking employees on,
I’m not interested in what building and

139
00:07:01.640 --> 00:07:02.880
scaling and whatever.

140
00:07:02.880 --> 00:07:06.340
And if that's your measure of success,
that is totally fine, don't get me wrong.

141
00:07:06.340 --> 00:07:08.570
>> But don't you ever wanna
spend time with your family?

142
00:07:08.570 --> 00:07:11.420
>> Well it doesn't mean that somebody who
has a lifestyle consultancy can't spend

143
00:07:11.420 --> 00:07:12.130
time with their family.

144
00:07:12.130 --> 00:07:13.870
They totally can.

145
00:07:13.870 --> 00:07:16.140
Again, those are measures of success.

146
00:07:16.140 --> 00:07:20.140
If your measure of success is to make
$100 million, inside of three years, and

147
00:07:20.140 --> 00:07:23.400
you've got a company that can do it,
congratulations that's fantastic

148
00:07:23.400 --> 00:07:27.260
by the way, but you'll have to work a
million hours a day, and I'm exaggerating

149
00:07:27.260 --> 00:07:30.780
bear with me, to do so, then you're
not gonna spend time with your family,

150
00:07:30.780 --> 00:07:32.320
you're not gonna spend time by yourself,

151
00:07:32.320 --> 00:07:36.540
you're not gonna spend time taking care
of your own health, your own sanity.

152
00:07:36.540 --> 00:07:38.909
And at the end of that year or
three years, or whatever it is,

153
00:07:38.909 --> 00:07:42.353
you're probably gonna be a blubbering
wreck, but you'll have the $100 million.

154
00:07:42.353 --> 00:07:43.584
Yeah.

155
00:07:43.584 --> 00:07:46.585
But you're a blubbering wreck,
not able to enjoy 100 million.

156
00:07:46.585 --> 00:07:50.160
>> So to help you with this,
I think a little bit if I may,

157
00:07:50.160 --> 00:07:53.970
spend time with family,
spend time with friends.

158
00:07:53.970 --> 00:07:55.356
Go and enjoy life.

159
00:07:55.356 --> 00:07:59.045
Your business is not the most
important thing you do.

160
00:07:59.045 --> 00:08:00.665
What it does is it pays your bills.

161
00:08:00.665 --> 00:08:03.419
>> Well ok, yes and no.

162
00:08:03.419 --> 00:08:07.812
It pays your bills but it also allows you
to have quality time with your family.

163
00:08:07.812 --> 00:08:09.209
>> Right.
>> Money is not happiness.

164
00:08:09.209 --> 00:08:11.931
Money is not happiness.

165
00:08:11.931 --> 00:08:14.416
But it certainly allows you to buy some
fun times to help create happy memories.

166
00:08:14.416 --> 00:08:16.244
>> It helps, yeah.

167
00:08:16.244 --> 00:08:18.190
>> You have a young daughter.

168
00:08:18.190 --> 00:08:18.860
>> I do.

169
00:08:18.860 --> 00:08:21.420
>> And you adore her.

170
00:08:21.420 --> 00:08:22.030
>> Yep.

171
00:08:22.030 --> 00:08:24.230
>> She is really, really, really cute.

172
00:08:24.230 --> 00:08:25.660
She's adorable.

173
00:08:25.660 --> 00:08:29.790
And spending time with her, I see your
face light up when you get to do it

174
00:08:29.790 --> 00:08:32.060
It is one of the most
amazing times in your life.

175
00:08:32.060 --> 00:08:35.380
You just absolutely adore her and
the time you spend with your wife and

176
00:08:35.380 --> 00:08:37.500
your little one, you're happy.

177
00:08:37.500 --> 00:08:38.370
That is wonderful.

178
00:08:38.370 --> 00:08:39.830
>> It's the same with you and your dog.

179
00:08:39.830 --> 00:08:42.628
It's actually kind of funny.

180
00:08:42.628 --> 00:08:43.402
>> My dog is so cute.

181
00:08:43.402 --> 00:08:45.730
>> I'm also including your
wife in this mixture.

182
00:08:45.730 --> 00:08:53.427
But you know it's the little
things that really make it for us.

183
00:08:53.427 --> 00:08:57.112
As we're running Red Lion and
we're bringing it off the ground,

184
00:08:57.112 --> 00:09:01.534
it's the little things, the little
chances, the little nuggets of time that

185
00:09:01.534 --> 00:09:06.023
we get to spend with our loved ones, that
we get to go and hug a loved one, right,

186
00:09:06.023 --> 00:09:10.170
are what we really,
really value as being precious and wealth.

187
00:09:10.170 --> 00:09:15.150
>> And as entrepreneurs, if you don't
value those things, you are in trouble.

188
00:09:15.150 --> 00:09:19.620
You will not, not,
not live a quality life.

189
00:09:19.620 --> 00:09:23.290
If you have loved ones, and if you don't I
apologize, I'm not trying to be rude, but

190
00:09:23.290 --> 00:09:24.790
if you don't, you've got friends.

191
00:09:24.790 --> 00:09:25.552
Make some friends.

192
00:09:25.552 --> 00:09:27.160
Go have time with friends.

193
00:09:27.160 --> 00:09:30.870
Make sure you have a life and take care
of yourself along with your business.

194
00:09:30.870 --> 00:09:34.270
The better quality life you have,
the better quality business you'll have.

195
00:09:34.270 --> 00:09:35.080
I guarantee it.

196
00:09:36.080 --> 00:09:36.590
>> Yep.

197
00:09:36.590 --> 00:09:39.030
So to wrap all of this up.

198
00:09:39.030 --> 00:09:43.920
There are many facets to
the entrepreneurial roller coaster, right?

199
00:09:43.920 --> 00:09:44.748
>> Absolutely.
>> And so

200
00:09:44.748 --> 00:09:49.343
it all depends on what you wanna
do with your life, with your job,

201
00:09:49.343 --> 00:09:53.930
with your business and
how you run things, right?

202
00:09:53.930 --> 00:09:55.500
>> Look, it all matters.

203
00:09:55.500 --> 00:09:57.830
Having money is fantastic,
having a good family and

204
00:09:57.830 --> 00:10:00.410
a good wonderful set
loved ones is fantastic.

205
00:10:00.410 --> 00:10:02.582
These are all good things, okay?

206
00:10:02.582 --> 00:10:06.470
It's a balance, it's moderation.

207
00:10:06.470 --> 00:10:09.848
You know, if you spend a year and you sit
down with your wife, or your husband, or

208
00:10:09.848 --> 00:10:11.438
your spouse or your loved one and say,

209
00:10:11.438 --> 00:10:14.222
this next year I'm gonna be working
on the business exclusively,

210
00:10:14.222 --> 00:10:16.920
like there is nothing in my life but
business for a year.

211
00:10:16.920 --> 00:10:17.790
That's fine.

212
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:20.750
That's a choice that you make between
the two of you, the three of you,

213
00:10:20.750 --> 00:10:22.480
the ten of you,
whatever it is I don't care.

214
00:10:23.560 --> 00:10:26.830
But what matters is, is that you
make these choices, you communicate,

215
00:10:26.830 --> 00:10:31.320
you spend time, you balance and
moderate your life, okay?

216
00:10:31.320 --> 00:10:32.452
If you don't do that,

217
00:10:32.452 --> 00:10:35.561
you will not be healthy enough
to get your company to success.

218
00:10:35.561 --> 00:10:38.830
If you don't do that, you will not be
healthy enough to get a job if it fails.

219
00:10:38.830 --> 00:10:40.473
And that always has to be
in your head by the way.

220
00:10:40.473 --> 00:10:44.176
>> And you will never ever get over
your entrepreneurial roller coaster.

221
00:10:44.176 --> 00:10:44.754
>> Damn straight.

222
00:10:44.754 --> 00:10:46.620
>> So, thanks for watching.

223
00:10:46.620 --> 00:10:47.555
I'm Scott.

224
00:10:47.555 --> 00:10:48.850
>> I'm Josh.

225
00:10:48.850 --> 00:10:51.528
>> And you are watching BIZPRO.TV

226
00:10:53.360 --> 00:10:58.326
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: How not to be a CEO
episodes.title: How not to be a CEO

episodes.description: When not to join a Start-up
episodes.title: When not to join a Start-up

episodes.description: Zero Knowledge doesn't mean Zero Ethics
episodes.title: Zero Knowledge doesn't mean Zero Ethics
Keeping Track of your Expenses
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.947
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.947 --> 00:00:08.743
>> Hi, and welcome to BizPro.TV FireTalks.

3
00:00:08.743 --> 00:00:12.060
Today, we're gonna be talking about
how to keep track of your expenses.

4
00:00:12.060 --> 00:00:14.568
So let's start off with the very
simple stuff, like my name.

5
00:00:14.568 --> 00:00:16.470
Hi, I'm Joshua Marpet.

6
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:18.120
I'm the COO of Red Lion.

7
00:00:18.120 --> 00:00:22.030
You can reach me at jmarpet@redlion.io
if you have any questions.

8
00:00:22.030 --> 00:00:22.644
Scott?

9
00:00:22.644 --> 00:00:28.542
>> Hi, I'm Scott, I'm the CEO, although
titles are relative, CEO of Red Lion.

10
00:00:28.542 --> 00:00:34.240
You can reach me at slyons@redlion.io
if you have any questions.

11
00:00:34.240 --> 00:00:38.300
So Josh, running a business is fun.

12
00:00:38.300 --> 00:00:39.136
>> No.

13
00:00:39.136 --> 00:00:41.090
>> Its' horrifying you're saying?

14
00:00:41.090 --> 00:00:43.490
>> It's a serious pain in the buns.

15
00:00:43.490 --> 00:00:44.350
Lets be honest.

16
00:00:44.350 --> 00:00:46.566
There's enough paperwork
to kill a small horse.

17
00:00:46.566 --> 00:00:50.324
There's enough stress to kill a large
horse or an elephant at that point.

18
00:00:50.324 --> 00:00:52.838
>> Right.
>> And it's occasionally fun when you win,

19
00:00:52.838 --> 00:00:56.559
and it's a lot of grind, and a lot of
slog to get to those winning points.

20
00:00:56.559 --> 00:00:59.293
>> Yeah, but it all depends on
how you keep track of all of it,-

21
00:00:59.293 --> 00:00:59.976
>> Yeah, this is true.

22
00:00:59.976 --> 00:01:04.722
>> Because there's multiple reasons
that you need to keep track of things,

23
00:01:04.722 --> 00:01:10.247
whether it be for taxes, for paperwork,
for, I don't know, just SNGs, right?

24
00:01:10.247 --> 00:01:10.884
>> Of course.
>> So,

25
00:01:10.884 --> 00:01:15.156
how do we go about keeping track
of expenses because we've got,

26
00:01:15.156 --> 00:01:20.548
just coming down here for ITPro and doing
what we're doing for you to watch this.

27
00:01:20.548 --> 00:01:24.977
We've got flight, hotel, car,
we've got gas, we've got food.

28
00:01:24.977 --> 00:01:25.507
>> Absolutely.

29
00:01:25.507 --> 00:01:27.024
>> What other incidentals?

30
00:01:27.024 --> 00:01:28.301
How do we track them?

31
00:01:28.301 --> 00:01:30.370
Let's dive.

32
00:01:30.370 --> 00:01:35.130
>> Okay, so keeping track of your expenses
use to be a very, very simple process.

33
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:37.900
At the end of a trip you had
a wallet full of crumpled receipts,

34
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:41.116
that you would carefully extract from
that bear trap known as a wallet.

35
00:01:41.116 --> 00:01:45.027
You pull them out, stretch them out,
realize that the thermal printing faded

36
00:01:45.027 --> 00:01:49.351
four days ago, and you're having to guess
everything that's on it, tape them down to

37
00:01:49.351 --> 00:01:53.376
a piece of paper, write everything out on
another piece of paper and total it up,

38
00:01:53.376 --> 00:01:57.228
fill out a form on some antiquated excel
spreadsheet that has macros that were

39
00:01:57.228 --> 00:02:01.493
designed by cave men, and then, eventually
your HR or expense department would give

40
00:02:01.493 --> 00:02:05.284
you back a piece of paper that basically
said we can't read these receipts,

41
00:02:05.284 --> 00:02:06.995
we're not giving you any money.

42
00:02:06.995 --> 00:02:10.208
>> And so,
you're saying you have to manually OCR, or

43
00:02:10.208 --> 00:02:13.700
optical character recognize,
your own receipts?

44
00:02:13.700 --> 00:02:17.015
>> It was bad in the old days, let me
tell you something, it was horrible.

45
00:02:17.015 --> 00:02:18.221
I remember having,-
>> Back in my day.

46
00:02:18.221 --> 00:02:19.431
>> A binder,-
>> [LAUGH]

47
00:02:19.431 --> 00:02:21.115
>> A binder full of receipts for

48
00:02:21.115 --> 00:02:22.803
a one month trip that I took.

49
00:02:22.803 --> 00:02:24.860
It was pitiful.

50
00:02:24.860 --> 00:02:28.200
Nowadays there's so
many more easier ways to do it.

51
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:30.356
We personally use Expensify.

52
00:02:30.356 --> 00:02:32.235
Expensify is literally
an app on your phone.

53
00:02:32.235 --> 00:02:34.643
You take a picture of
the receipt with the camera.

54
00:02:34.643 --> 00:02:36.995
The app actually takes the receipt and

55
00:02:36.995 --> 00:02:38.866
sends it off to be OCR'd-
>> Yep.

56
00:02:38.866 --> 00:02:39.990
>> By a human,-
>> Yep.

57
00:02:39.990 --> 00:02:42.602
>> So it's not digital OCR,
or mechanical OCR.

58
00:02:42.602 --> 00:02:46.530
They put in the amount, the name of
the restaurant or whatever the expense is.

59
00:02:46.530 --> 00:02:49.988
They even put in a category sometimes if
it's blatantly easy for them to do so.

60
00:02:49.988 --> 00:02:53.320
Then at the end of the day you say
well this was for this client.

61
00:02:53.320 --> 00:02:57.687
It's billable and reimbursable, or
it's not reimbursable or whatever, and

62
00:02:57.687 --> 00:03:01.076
it was this category of thing
that happened, food, travel,

63
00:03:01.076 --> 00:03:01.970
hotel,-
>> Yep.

64
00:03:01.970 --> 00:03:06.075
>> Yadda-yadda, you get the idea, and it
generates a PDF with a lovely spreadsheet

65
00:03:06.075 --> 00:03:09.528
looking expense report form and
pictures of all the receipts without

66
00:03:09.528 --> 00:03:13.770
the thermal printing problem, because
believe me, that's still a problem.

67
00:03:13.770 --> 00:03:21.175
>> Now Expensify also has data connectors,
right, which will allow it to export and

68
00:03:21.175 --> 00:03:24.601
import data as needed from other-
>> Applications.

69
00:03:24.601 --> 00:03:25.742
>> Other applications.

70
00:03:25.742 --> 00:03:28.532
>> Absolutely.
>> Like if you need to throw out invoices

71
00:03:28.532 --> 00:03:32.945
on a regular basis, right,
there are application integrations for

72
00:03:32.945 --> 00:03:35.166
invoicing, that Expensify has.

73
00:03:35.166 --> 00:03:41.610
Another really good expense tracking
piece of software is Concur.

74
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:44.288
>> Concur is more for larger corporations.

75
00:03:44.288 --> 00:03:47.667
It's designed to have more rules and
approvals and things like that.

76
00:03:47.667 --> 00:03:52.012
So Scott may only be authorized
up to $300 for a car or

77
00:03:52.012 --> 00:03:56.090
he can only stay at Hilton or
these kinds of things.

78
00:03:56.090 --> 00:03:59.690
It's much more workflow
oriented than Expensify.

79
00:03:59.690 --> 00:04:02.500
Expensify works for one person,
there's a free version even.

80
00:04:02.500 --> 00:04:05.440
So obviously, it depends on what type
of business you are as to which type of

81
00:04:05.440 --> 00:04:06.933
package you're going to pick up, but

82
00:04:06.933 --> 00:04:09.004
those are the two big ones
that I know about at least.

83
00:04:09.004 --> 00:04:11.833
>> Right, but when you're looking for

84
00:04:11.833 --> 00:04:14.925
a good expense tracking system,-
>> Right.

85
00:04:14.925 --> 00:04:18.181
>> Okay, there's a couple of things
that you really wanna look for

86
00:04:18.181 --> 00:04:20.560
in the system as far as usability goes.

87
00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:21.772
So portability.

88
00:04:21.772 --> 00:04:22.272
>> Right.

89
00:04:22.272 --> 00:04:24.110
>> Right, that's always an issue.

90
00:04:24.110 --> 00:04:29.364
The usability of it, does it have
a great UI that is just intuitive?

91
00:04:29.364 --> 00:04:30.614
>> Well a lot of them do, but

92
00:04:30.614 --> 00:04:34.440
you gotta remember that it also
depends on what you're doing with it.

93
00:04:34.440 --> 00:04:37.608
Remember that I said that Concur
has a lot of workflow rules.

94
00:04:37.608 --> 00:04:42.109
If those workflow rules are setup properly
then your expenses should go in boom,

95
00:04:42.109 --> 00:04:43.307
boom, boom, done.

96
00:04:43.307 --> 00:04:46.504
If you're trying to break the rules
however, or you don't know the rules, or

97
00:04:46.504 --> 00:04:49.960
they're not clear to you, then it's gonna
very, very choppy sort of experience.

98
00:04:49.960 --> 00:04:50.760
It's very bad.

99
00:04:50.760 --> 00:04:53.333
It's gonna reject this, deny that, and

100
00:04:53.333 --> 00:04:56.871
you're stuck doing a lot of
work to try make things work.

101
00:04:56.871 --> 00:04:57.526
>> Right.
So

102
00:04:57.526 --> 00:05:01.862
the other piece that you wanna
look at is sustainability.

103
00:05:01.862 --> 00:05:05.430
You wanna look at where
the architecture sends your data.

104
00:05:05.430 --> 00:05:09.442
Does it send it to the cloud or
does it keep it locally on your device?

105
00:05:09.442 --> 00:05:13.666
>> And that’s for a privacy reasons, as
well as, what happens if I lose my device,

106
00:05:13.666 --> 00:05:15.540
I drop it in the river.

107
00:05:15.540 --> 00:05:18.855
Do I lose all of the receipts, which
could be thousands, and thousands, and

108
00:05:18.855 --> 00:05:19.882
thousands of dollars?

109
00:05:19.882 --> 00:05:23.534
So, if it’s a SaaS application,
and there’s a cloud backup,

110
00:05:23.534 --> 00:05:25.712
then I've got all my receipts still.

111
00:05:25.712 --> 00:05:28.593
I just get a new device,
login to my account.

112
00:05:28.593 --> 00:05:32.600
There's my thousands of dollars
I would have lost otherwise.

113
00:05:32.600 --> 00:05:36.335
On the other hand, if it's not on your
device, is it encrypted in the cloud so

114
00:05:36.335 --> 00:05:39.727
that it can only be opened by me, or
perhaps, the admin at my company,

115
00:05:39.727 --> 00:05:43.254
if it's a corporate application,
so that there's privacy involved?

116
00:05:43.254 --> 00:05:46.617
I don't want everybody to know what
restaurants I stayed at, sorry,

117
00:05:46.617 --> 00:05:49.242
what restaurants I ate at,
or what hotels I stayed at.

118
00:05:49.242 --> 00:05:52.292
There can be security implications,
especially if you're a target for

119
00:05:52.292 --> 00:05:53.493
physical security issues.

120
00:05:53.493 --> 00:05:54.304
>> Right, and so

121
00:05:54.304 --> 00:05:58.440
sometimes you don't even wanna use
any of the technology at all, okay.

122
00:05:58.440 --> 00:06:02.723
You sit back and
you say I'm sick of this, okay and

123
00:06:02.723 --> 00:06:08.600
hey a bag, works perfectly for
me or my accountant.

124
00:06:08.600 --> 00:06:13.150
>> Yeah look, accountants cost by
the hour, and if you wanna pay somebody to

125
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:19.700
spend hours and days cataloguing your
paper receipts, well that's your choice.

126
00:06:19.700 --> 00:06:24.607
But if you're a smart CEO, or a smart CFO,
you're gonna say why did we spend $800 to

127
00:06:24.607 --> 00:06:28.660
catalog your $10,000 worth of receipts for
one trip?

128
00:06:28.660 --> 00:06:33.300
Why don't we just have you use Expensify
or Concur, it's a heck of a lot cheaper?

129
00:06:33.300 --> 00:06:37.300
Unless, of course, you're here at ITPro,
and they have Shelly.

130
00:06:37.300 --> 00:06:40.168
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH] We actually talked to Don at

131
00:06:40.168 --> 00:06:45.511
ITPro, and he said, we used Expensify and
we had some issues with it.

132
00:06:45.511 --> 00:06:48.708
Shelly took it over, she was already
doing this, that, and other thing, and

133
00:06:48.708 --> 00:06:51.580
it works just fine for us, and
that's great, that's their choice.

134
00:06:51.580 --> 00:06:55.677
But they already had Shelly so
this is a very minor addition to her job,

135
00:06:55.677 --> 00:06:56.936
it's not a big deal.

136
00:06:56.936 --> 00:07:00.222
If, however, they started getting
traveling sales people going all over

137
00:07:00.222 --> 00:07:03.402
the world, or the country at least,
they would probably switch to one of

138
00:07:03.402 --> 00:07:07.590
the applications that actually do it for
them, because Shelly would be overwhelmed.

139
00:07:07.590 --> 00:07:09.600
Again, it goes back to cost and time.

140
00:07:09.600 --> 00:07:13.980
>> But the most important thing that they
did to figure it out was that they asked

141
00:07:13.980 --> 00:07:15.090
questions.

142
00:07:15.090 --> 00:07:15.971
>> They tried.

143
00:07:15.971 --> 00:07:19.802
They tried, and they asked questions, and
if you have questions about expenses,

144
00:07:19.802 --> 00:07:21.389
tracking, business paperwork,
